references.B98TEN01USGP: Tennant, A. 1998. A field guide to Texas snakes. Second edition. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.
references.B95WIL01NCGP: Wilson, L. A. 1995. The Land Manager's Guide to the amphibians and reptiles of the South. Chapel Hill, NC: The Nature Conservancy.

references.B70FIT01NAUS: Fitch, H. S. 1970. Reproductive cycles of lizards and snakes. Univ. Kansas Museum Natural History Miscellaneous Publication 52:1-247.

references.B90COL01NAUS: Collins, J. T. 1990. Standard common and current scientific names for North American amphibians and reptiles. SSAR Herpetol. Circular No. 19. 41 pp.
references.B88ASH01NAUS: Ashton, R. E., Jr., and P. S. Ashton. 1988. Handbook of reptiles and amphibians of Florida. Part Three. The amphibians. Windward Publ. Co., Miami.
references.B84TEN01NAUS: Tennant, A. 1984. The Snakes of Texas. Texas Monthly Press, Austin, Texas. 561 pp.
references.B79BEH01NAUS: Behler, J. L., and F. W. King. 1979. The Audubon Society field guide to North American reptiles and  amphibians. Alfred A. Knopf, New York. 719 pp.

references.B97TEN01USGP: Tennant, A. 1997. A field guide to snakes of Florida. Gulf Publishing Company, Houston, Texas.  257 pp.
references.B95PAL01NAUS: Palmer, W. M., and A. L. Braswell. 1995. Reptiles of North Carolina. North Carolina State Museum of Natural Sciences, University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, North Carolina.
references.B81ASH01NAUS: Ashton, R. E., Jr., and P. S. Ashton. 1981. Handbook of Reptiles and Amphibians of Florida. Part One:The Snakes. Windward Pub. Co., Miami, Florida. 176 pp.

references.B03ERN01USGP: Ernst, C. H., and E. M. Ernst. 2003. Snakes of the United States and Canada. Smithsonian Books, Washington, D.C.

habitat_description:
The range of this species extends across areas of southeastern Virginia, northern Florida, Texas, central Missouri, and extreme southwestern Tennessee (Conant and Collins 1991; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Mitchell 1994; Palmer and Braswell 1995; Powell et al. 1994; Werler and Dixon 2000).

This semi-fossorial snake is generally found in moist areas, heavily vegetated areas with some exposure to sunlight; also found in decaying stumps, under rocks, leaf litter, loose bark, or other cover. The habitat includes cropland, forest edge, herbaceous areas, grassland, conifer woodland, and suburban areas. In particular, this species occurs in rocky hillsides of dry open woods, woodland edge, heavily wooded bottomlands, pine flatwoods, pastures, limestone and sandstone cedar glades, dry and mesic hammocks, swamp borders and margins of streams of arid areas. Found often in gardens, orchards, vacant lots, and other suburban areas (Ernst and Ernst 2003; Mitchell 1994; Palmer and Braswell 1995; Trauth et al. 2004).

SE	-Found in vegetated areas composed of conifer woodland, forest edge, gardens, and orchards. Uses loose bark, fallen, logs, and leaf litter as cover.
